sub_topic: Population growth models using differential equations
message_1: A certain shark population starts with 500 individuals and grows at a rate proportional to the population size, with a constant of proportionality of 0.02. How many sharks will there be after 5 years?
message_2:
This problem can be solved using the exponential growth formula:

P(t) = P0 * e^(rt)

where P(t) is the population at time t, P0 is the initial population, r is the constant of proportionality, and t is the time in years.

In this case, P0 = 500, r = 0.02, and t = 5.

P(5) = 500 * e^(0.02 * 5)

P(5) = 500 * e^0.1

P(5) ≈ 500 * 1.10517

P(5) ≈ 552.585

After 5 years, there will be approximately 553 sharks in the population.
